Award.AwardTitle: Using two-photon polymerization for the fabrication of 3D matrices for cell migration studies

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0854288
E. Mazur

This NSF award by the Biosensing and Bioengineering/CBET program supports work by Professors Eric Mazur and David Mooney at Harvard University to study the role of material architecture and physical properties in 3D cell-cell interactions and motility using a two- photon fabrication technique. Using two-photon polymerization to fabricate 3D matrices, they study cell adhesion and migration in three dimensions. Cell migration research is taking intriguing new turns and emerging studies are revealing marked differences in the way that cells migrate in two versus three dimensions. Such studies are important to understand a variety of physiological and pathological processes such as progression of cancer, metastasis, and tissue regeneration. The main goal of this proposal is to develop a synthetic three-dimensional extracellular matrix (ECM) that permits independent and precise spatial control of biochemical and biophysical cues.

Specifically, they will develop two-photon polymerization system to fabricate three-dimensional matrix with varying physical and chemical properties. They will then perform a systematic study on cell migration by varying several parameters of the ECM in a controlled way. The effects of pore size and shape, mechanical-stiffness, adhesion peptide concentration of the ECM walls, degradation of the matrix on cell motility, and adhesion will be studied. This approach will allow them to have a precise, independent control over architecture as well as various adhesion and mechanical parameters at a micrometer and submicrometer scale to study their role in cell migration in a systematic manner. Finally, the proposed work will demonstrate the broad applicability of this approach to study various cell and tissue processes in isolation in order to address novel problems in biology.

Institution.Name: Harvard University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we combined the expertise from two different disciplines -- engineering and life sciences -- to further our understanding of the movement of cells. Using laser beams we fabricated a microscopic polymer "scaffold" in which we can observe the migration of cells under a microscope. The scaffolds we fabricated are the width of a human hair and can be coated with chemicals that influence cell motion and tissue formation. By combinging the optical tools developed by one group to manipulate matter at the micro- and nanoscale, with the expertise of another group in controlling the microenvironment of mammalian cells, the researchers funded by this group were able to shed new light on the migration of cells in three dimensions. 

The system that we have developed using the technique of two-photon polymerization of interconnected scaffolds and subsequent live cell imaging in a controlled chemotactic chamber has allowed us to study the chemotactic response and migration of immune cells like dendritic cells. It is also helping us look at other cell systems like endothelial cells, mesenchymal stem cells and leukemia cells, and thus have a broader impact in the field of tissue engineering. 

The live imaging system and the fabrication set-up also allows us to study other problems in biology. Apart from the different cell systems, the scaffolds we built will permit looking at the interaction of different cell types and the paracrine effect of the cells on other cell types in this chemotactic setting. 

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2013
Modified by: Eric Mazur
